item.title: Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma
item.description: ![[z_attachments/Pasted image 20240125141057.png]] [!danger] Medical emergency Sudden increase in intraocular pressure Caused by blockage of the drainage angle in the eye Not cancer related !

item.title: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo
item.description: Occurs on head movement due to disruption of small calcium crystals (canolithiasis) in the inner ear which can stimulate nerve endings causing dizziness

item.title: Blepharitis
item.description: Common chronic inflammatory condition affecting the margin of the eyelids Mixed anterior and posterior can occur ![[z_attachments/Pasted image 20240207125654.png|425]] Causes/Factors Anterior blepharitis - inflammation of the base of the eyelashes - caused by bacteria (usually staph) or seborrhoeic dermatitis

item.title: Chronic Closed Angle Glaucoma
item.description: ![[z_attachments/Pasted image 20240125141057.png]] Causes/Factors Increasing age Family history Black ethnic origin Myopia (nearsightedness) Clinical Features Glaucoma affects the peripheral vision first, resulting in a gradual onset of peripheral vision loss (tunnel vision).

item.title: Conjunctivitis
item.description: Inflammation of the conjunctiva Causes/Factors Bacterial Infection: Caused by bacteria such as Staphylococcus or Streptococcus. Viral Infection: Viruses, including adenoviruses, often lead to infectious conjunctivitis.

item.title: Eyelid Disorders
item.description: [[Blepharitis]] Inflammation of the eyelid margins Itchy, gritty, dry sensation Can be associated with dysfunction of the Meibomain glands which are responsible for secreting meibum (oil) onto the surface of the eye.

item.title: Infective Keratitis
item.description: [!danger] Sight threatening infection Inflammation of the cornea Bacterial and viral are the most common - rarely fungal or protozoan Pathogens Clinical features Management Bacterial - Pseudomonas spp.

item.title: Obesity
item.description: A BMI >$30 kg/m^3$ Obesity is a chronic condition characterized by the accumulation of excess body fat, leading to adverse health effects.

item.title: Orbital cellulitis
item.description: Infection that involves the muscle and fat within the orbit - posterior to the orbital septum More common in children than adults - 16x more

item.title: Periorbital cellulitis
item.description: An infection in the eyelid tissues anterior to the orbital septum Much more common and less serious than [[Orbital cellulitis]]

item.title: Thyroid Eye Disease
item.description: Autoimmune condition associated with [[Grave’s disease]] seen in 25-50% of people with Graves'. Due to a specific immune response that causes retro-orbital inflammation.
